sen.j: 西園寺 公望（さいおんじ きんもち、嘉永2年10月23日 (旧暦)（1849年12月7日） - 昭和15年（1940年）11月24日）は日本の公家､政治家。
sen.e: Kimmochi SAIONJI (December 7, 1849 - November 24, 1940) was a Japanese Court noble and a politician.
Kimmochi SAIONJI (December 7, 1849 - November 24, 1940) was a noble in the Japanese Court and a politician.
Kinmochi SAIONJI (December 7, 1849 - November 24, 1940) was a noble in the Japanese Court and a politician.

sen.j: 立憲政友会第2代総裁。
sen.e: The second President of Rikken Seiyu-kai Party.
The second President of the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party.
The second President of the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party.

sen.j: 第12・14代内閣総理大臣。
sen.e: The 12th and 14th Prime Minister of Japan.
He was the 12th and the 14th Prime Minister of Japan.
sen.cmt: This refers to one person, Kimmochi SAIONJI, not two: http://wapedia.mobi/en/Saionji_Kinmochi
sen.e: He was the twelfth and the fourteenth Prime Minister of Japan.

sen.j: 贈従一位、大勲位、大勲位菊花章頸飾、公爵。
sen.e: He was awarded junior first court rank and the highest honorary order in Japan, Collar of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum; prince.
sen.cmt: 大勲位 = 勲一等の上位で、日本最高の勲等。大勲位菊花章頸飾・大勲位菊花大綬章がある。出典：『辞林２１』三省堂、 highest honorary order in Japan, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: He was awarded the title of Juichi (junior first court rank) and the highest honorary order in Japan, Collar of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum; prince.
sen.cmt: IMPORTANT: I added Juichi here because files I have previously worked on (68302, 79785) used it as well. More importantly, because there are only commas and no grammatical markers, I have no idea what the relationship between the honorary order, the collar of the supreme order, and prince are. Specifically, are they the same award, or different.. If the same, add, "which is called the"
sen.e: He was awarded the title of Juichi (Junior First Rank) and the highest honorary order in Japan, Collar of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum; and appointed a prince.
sen.cmt: (Junior First Rank)で統一原文の「公爵」=「公爵の位を与えられた」と解釈しました。。

sen.j: 本姓は藤原。
sen.e: His real surname was FUJIWARA.
His real surname was FUJIWARA.
His real surname was FUJIWARA.

sen.j: 正式には藤原公望（ふじわら の きんもち）。
sen.e: Officially, FUJIWARA no Kimmochi.
Officially, he was called FUJIWARA no Kimmochi.
sen.cmt: I know that this is not in the Japanese, but consider adding "he was called" or the like to the English.
sen.e: Officially, he was called FUJIWARA no Kinmochi.

sen.j: 大正13年（1924年）に松方正義が死去した後は、「最後の元老」として大正天皇、昭和天皇を輔弼した。
sen.e: He served as a political advisor to Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa as "the last Genro (oligarch)" after Masayoshi MATSUKATA died in 1924.
sen.cmt: 「最後の元老」 = "the last Genro (oligarch)", 元老： "Japan - From Prehistory to Modern Times" by John Whitney Hall; Published by the Charles E. Tuttle Company Inc.; 輔弼（ほひつ）する = serve as a political advisor, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: He served as a political advisor to Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa as "the last Genro (oligarch)" after Masayoshi MATSUKATA died in 1924.
He served as a political advisor to Emperor Taisho and Emperor Showa as 'the last Genro (oligarch)' after Masayoshi MATSUKATA died in 1924.

sen.j: また文化人、趣味人としても名高く、陶庵と号し書を能くし、叙情あふれる漢詩も多く残している。
sen.e: He was also well-known as a man of culture and hobbies; he was a talented poet who left many lyrical Chinese-style poems under the pen name of Toan.
sen.cmt: 漢詩 = Chinese-style poem, 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: He was also well-known as a man of culture and hobbies his hobbies distinguished him; he was a talented poet who left many lyrical Chinese-style poems under the pen name of Toan.
sen.cmt: "man of culture" sounds native.. But "man of hobbies" sounds odd. Man of leisure is native but the connotation is different, consider, "…as a man of culture and his hobbies distinguished him" or some alternative..
sen.e: He was also well-known as a man of culture and his hobbies distinguished him; he was a talented poet who left many lyrical Chinese-style poems under the pen name of Toan.

sen.j: また森鴎外ら第一級の文人たちを招じ雨声会と称したサロンを主催した。
sen.e: He also hosted a salon named Usei-kai, inviting foremost littérateurs including Ogai MORI.
He also hosted a salon called Usei-kai, which invited foremost littérateurs including Ogai MORI.
He also hosted a salon called Usei-kai, which invited foremost litterateur including Ogai MORI.

sen.j: 西園寺公望は清華家の一つ徳大寺家の次男として誕生し、4歳の時に、同族で清華家の西園寺家へ養子に入り家督を相続した。
sen.e: Kimmochi SAIONJI was born as the second son of Tokudaiji Family, which is one of the Seigake Families, but at the age of 4 he was adopted by the SAIONJI Family, which also belongs to the Seigake Family, and he took over as the head of the family.
sen.cmt: 家督 = take over as head of the Family, 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Kimmochi SAIONJI was born as the second son of the Tokudaiji Family, which is one of the Seigake Families, but at the age of 4 he was adopted by the SAIONJI Family, which also belonged to the Seigake Family, and he took over as the head of the family.
sen.cmt: added "the" tenses. I left "belonged" but another verb might be better, "was under" for example.
sen.e: Kinmochi SAIONJI was born as the second son of the Tokudaiji Family, which is one of the Seigake Families, but at the age of 4 he was adopted by the Saionji Family, which also belonged to the Seigake Family, and he took over as the head of the family.

sen.j: 両家は藤原房前を始祖とする藤原北家閑院流の血筋の系統である。
sen.e: Both families belong genealogically to the Hokke Fujiwara Kanin Line that has FUJIWARA no Fusasaki as the patriarch.
Both families belong genealogically to the Hokke Fujiwara Kanin Line, of which FUJIWARA no Fusasaki was the patriarch.
sen.cmt: that has --> of which as--> was
sen.e: Both families belong genealogically to the Hokke Fujiwara Kanin Line, of which FUJIWARA no Fusasaki was the patriarch.

sen.j: 実父は右大臣徳大寺公純、実兄は3度にわたって侍従長となり、内大臣もつとめた徳大寺実則。
sen.e: His biological father was Kinito TOKUDAIJI, Minister of the Right, and his older biological brother was Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, who served as the Grand Chamberlain 3 times and as Minister of the Imperial Household.
sen.cmt: 侍従長 = Grand Chamberlain, 英辞郎 on the WEB; 内大臣 = Minister of the Imperial Household, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: His biological father was Kinito TOKUDAIJI, Minister of the Right, and his older biological brother was Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, who served as the Grand Chamberlain three times and as Minister of the Imperial Household.

His biological father was Kinito TOKUDAIJI, Udaijin (Minister of the Right), and his older biological brother was Sanetsune TOKUDAIJI, who served as the Grand Chamberlain three times and as Minister of the Imperial Household.
sen.cmt: Minister of the Right→Udaijin (Minister of the Right)に変更しました。

sen.j: すぐ下の弟の隆麿は住友家の入り婿となり、住友財閥を継いで第15代住友吉左衛門（住友友純）を襲名し、長く財界に君臨した。
sen.e: His immediate younger brother, Takamaro, married into the Sumitomo Family, and he took over Sumitomo Zaibatsu and succeeded Kichizaemon SUMITOMO, the 15th (Tomoito SUMITOMO), and he reigned the financial world for a long time.

The younger brother of Kimmochi SAIONJI closest in age to him, Takamaro, married into the Sumitomo Family, and he took over Sumitomo Zaibatsu and succeeded Kichizaemon SUMITOMO the 15th (Tomoito SUMITOMO), and he reigned the financial world for a long time.
sen.cmt: This was a very big change for a very small problem. "immediate younger brother" is a bit abnormal, and that makes it hard to interpret correctly. As a result, I readded the subject, in the phrase, "of Kimmochi SAIONJI closest in age to him," removed comma.
sen.e: The younger brother of Kinmochi SAIONJI closest in age to him, Takamaro, married into the Sumitomo Family, and he took over Sumitomo Zaibatsu and succeeded Kichizaemon SUMITOMO the fifteenth (Tomoito SUMITOMO), and he reigned the financial world for a long time.

sen.j: そして、末弟の末弘威麿は母方の末弘家を継ぎ、後に京都法政学校（現在の立命館大学）の幹事・理事などを務めている。
sen.e: Furthermore, his youngest brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, took over as the head of the SUEHIRO Family on his mother's side, and he later served as an organizer and a board member of Kyoto Law and Policy School (present day Ritsumeikan University).

Furthermore, his youngest brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, took over as the head of the SUEHIRO Family on his mother's side, and he later served as an organizer and a board member at Kyoto Law and Policy School (now Ritsumeikan University).
sen.cmt: was "Kyoto Law and Policy School " verified? No source is given. I checked it but it returned 0 hits on google… of --> at
sen.e: Furthermore, his youngest brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, took over as the head of the SUEHIRO Family on his mother's side, and he later served as an organizer and a board member at Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school (now Ritsumeikan University).
sen.cmt: 京都法政学校→Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school [http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/eng/profile/history/index.shtml]

sen.j: 幼少時には、住まいが御所に近く、年齢も近かったことから、祐宮（のちの明治天皇）の遊び相手として度々召された。
sen.e: When he was young, he was often sent to play with Sachino-miya (later Emperor Meiji) because he lived near Gosho (Imperial Palace) and because they were close in age.
During his youth, he was often sent to play with Sachino-miya (later Emperor Meiji) because he lived near Gosho (the Imperial Palace) and because they were close in age.
sen.cmt: Changed to "during his youth" added "the". Consider adding "the" again before "gosho"
sen.e: During his youth, he was often sent to play with Sachinomiya (later Emperor Meiji) because he lived near Gosho (the Imperial Palace) and because they were close in age.

tit.e: The end of Edo period and the Meiji Restoration
The end of the Edo period and the Meiji Restoration
The end of the Edo period and the Meiji Restoration

sen.j: 西園寺には、岩倉具視や三条実美のような幕末期における政治的功績はほとんど皆無であった。
sen.e: Unlike Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanetomi SANJO, SAIONJI had virtually no political achievement at the end of Edo period.
Unlike Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanetomi SANJO, SAIONJI had virtually no political achievements by the end of Edo period.
Unlike Tomomi IWAKURA and Sanetomi SANJO, Saionji had virtually no political achievements by the end of Edo period.

sen.j: ただ鳥羽・伏見の戦いがはじまると、朝廷ではこれを徳川家と島津家の私闘と見なす意見が出るなかにあって、積極的な関与・主戦論を主張し岩倉ら倒幕派公卿に注目された。
sen.e: However, when the Battle of Toba Fushimi broke out, even though there were opinions within the Imperial Court that viewed it as a personal battle between the Tokugawa Family and the Shimazu Family, he asserted active involvement and advocated the battle, thereby drawing attention from Court nobles who wanted to overthrow the Shogunate, such as IWAKURA.
sen.cmt: 倒幕派公卿 = Court nobles who wanted to overthrow the Shogunate (用語集の訳語を一部のみ変更)
sen.e: However, when the Battle of Toba Fushimi broke out, even though there were opinions within the Imperial Court that viewed it as a personal battle between the Tokugawa Family and the Shimazu Family, he suggested active involvement in the battle and advocated it, thereby drawing attention from Court nobles who wanted to overthrow the Shogunate, such as IWAKURA.
sen.cmt: asserted --> suggested consider another word such as recommended, etc., instead
sen.e: However, when the Battle of Toba Fushimi broke out, even though there were opinions within the Imperial Court that viewed it as a personal battle between the Tokugawa Family and the Shimazu Family, he suggested active involvement in the battle and advocated it, thereby drawing attention from Court nobles who wanted to overthrow the Shogunate, such as Iwakura.

sen.j: 以後の戊辰戦争では山陰道鎮撫総督、会津口征討大参謀として各地を転戦する。
sen.e: During Boshin War that followed, he fought in various locations serving as the Admiral of Sanin-do repression and as a Senior Staff to subdue Aizu-guchi.
sen.cmt: 山陰道鎮撫総督 = Admiral of Sanin-do repression, 「定訳不明」; 会津口征討大参謀 = Senior Staff to subdue Aizu-guchi, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: Following this, during the Boshin War, he fought in various locations serving as the Admiral of Sanin-do repression and as a Senior Staff to subdue Aizu-guchi.
sen.cmt: added "the" moved following this because putting it first makes Boshin seem less like adjectival… the phrase "admiral of sanin-do repression" does not make a lot of sense to me. Does it mean "an admiral in the sanin-do repression" ? If so that might be better
sen.e: Following this, during the Boshin War, he fought in various locations serving as the Admiral in the sanin-do repression and as a Senior Staff to subdue Aizu-guchi.
sen.cmt: "Admiral in the sanin-do repression" is better.

sen.j: その後は越後府知事などを歴任したが、その当時、西園寺は10代の青年であり、この若さで任官できたのは家格の後光以外に理由を見出すことは困難である。
sen.e: After that, he served as the Governor of Echigo Prefecture, but at that time, SAIONJI was a young man only in his teens, and it is difficult to find reasons other than his family connections for being able to take on such a position at such a young age.

After that, he served in positions such as the Governorship of Echigo Prefecture, but at that time, SAIONJI was a young man only in his teens, and it is difficult to find reasons other than his family connections for his being able to take on such a position at such a young age.
sen.cmt: added "such as" because of など. "young man only in his teens" is a bit redundant, but perhaps OK.
sen.e: After that, he served in positions such as the Governorship of Echigo Prefecture, but at that time, Saionji was a young man only in his teens, and it is difficult to find reasons other than his family connections for his being able to take on such a position at such a young age.

sen.j: また公卿の中で初めて洋服で宮中に参内し、未だ多く残る攘夷公卿の怒りを買ったエピソードも自著（『陶庵随筆』）で披瀝している。
sen.e: He also described in "Toan Essay" he authored about an episode of angering the large number of court nobles who were still pro-Joi (expulsion of barbarians), by being the first person among the court nobles to visit the Imperial Palace wearing a western-style clothes.

He also described in the "Toan Essay," which he authored, an episode in which he angered a large number of court nobles who were still pro-Joi (expulsion of the "barbarians"), by being the first person among the court nobles to visit the Imperial Palace wearing western-style clothing.
sen.cmt: several stylistic changes in first clause. Granted this will be read by Western tourists, it might be unwise to call them barbarians, even if this is how they were thought of, so I added quotation marks.
sen.e: He also described in the "Toan Essay," which he authored, an episode in which he angered a large number of court nobles who were still pro-Joi (expulsion of the "barbarians"), by being the first person among the court nobles to visit the Imperial Palace wearing western-style clothing.

sen.j: 官を辞した西園寺はフランス留学を考えるようになり、東京や長崎でフランス語の勉強を始めた。
sen.e: After he resigned from his government position he began to consider studying in France, and he started to study French in Tokyo and Nagasaki.
After he resigned from his government position, he began to consider studying in France, and he started to study French in Tokyo and Nagasaki.
After he resigned from his government position, he began to consider studying in France, and he started to study French in Tokyo and Nagasaki.

sen.j: 東京では前原一誠と同じ宿で長く一緒に過ごし、次第に武士の社会に馴染むと公家風の名を嫌って「望一郎」と名乗ったこともあった。
sen.e: In Tokyo, he stayed in the same boarding house as Issei MAEBARA for a long time, and when he gradually became familiar with the samurai society he grew to disliked his name as a court noble and used to call himself "Boichiro."

In Tokyo, he stayed in the same boarding house as Issei MAEBARA for a long time, and as he gradually became familiar with the samurai society he grew to dislike his name as a court noble and to call himself "Boichiro."
sen.cmt: "when" and "gradually" together --> X "as" and "gradually" OK disliked --> dislike deleted "used"
sen.e: In Tokyo, he stayed in the same boarding house as Issei MAEBARA for a long time, and as he gradually became familiar with the samurai society he grew to dislike his name as a court noble and to call himself 'Boichiro.'

sen.j: 若き日の西園寺が大小を差した侍姿で颯爽と立つ勇ましい写真も残されている。
sen.e: There is a picture of SAIONJI in his younger days wearing two swords and standing gallantly.
There is a picture of SAIONJI in his younger days wearing two swords and standing gallantly in the fashion of a samurai.
sen.cmt: in the fashion of a samurai: 侍姿で
sen.e: There is a picture of Saionji in his younger days wearing two swords and standing gallantly in the fashion of a samurai.

sen.j: やがて大村益次郎の推薦によって明治4年（1871年）、官費でフランスに留学した（のちに減額を申し出ている）。
sen.e: Soon, on the recommendation of Masujiro OMURA, in 1871, he went to study abroad in France on government funding (he later requested for a reduction in the fees).
sen.cmt: "のちに減額を申し出ている"の意味不明
sen.e: Soon, at the recommendation of Masujiro OMURA, in 1871, he went to study abroad in France on government funding (he later requested for a reduction of these funds).
sen.cmt: on--> at If "fees" is written, it sounds like the request was made to the French University, but I think it means he requested that his own income be reduced.
sen.e: Soon, at the recommendation of Masujiro OMURA, in 1871, he went to study abroad in France on government funding (he later requested for a reduction of these funds).

sen.j: 礼を言うために大村のいる旅館を訪れる直前、親友（万里小路通房）が駆け込んできて長談義となり、その間に大村益次郎が襲撃されるという事件が起こっている（明治2年）。
sen.e: Just before he visited the inn where OMURA was staying to say thank you to him, his best friend (Michifusa MADENOKOJI) came rushing in and they talked for a long time, during which time Masujiro OMURA was attacked (1869).

Just before he visited the inn where OMURA was staying to thank him, his best friend (Michifusa MADENOKOJI) came rushing in and they talked for a long time, during which time Masujiro OMURA was attacked (1869).

Just before he visited the inn where Omura was staying to thank him, his best friend (Michifusa MADENOKOJI) came rushing in and they talked for a long time, during which time Masujiro OMURA was attacked (1869).

sen.j: フランス行きの船内では、地球が球体であることを得心したり、白人少年に別れのキスを求められてとまどうといったエピソードがあったことが本人の手紙にしたためられている。
sen.e: Episodes that took place aboard the ship to France were noted in his letters, such as he became convinced that the Earth was spherical and that he was bewildered when he was asked for a kiss by a young Caucasian boy upon parting from each other.

Episodes that took place aboard the ship to France were noted in his letters, such as his becoming convinced that the Earth was spherical, or the time when he was bewildered because he was asked for a kiss by a young Caucasian boy upon parting from each other.
sen.cmt: he became --> his becoming and --> or the time when makes the sentence sound more like a list of episodes.
sen.e: Episodes that took place aboard the ship to France were noted in his letters, such as his becoming convinced that the Earth was spherical, or the time when he was bewildered because he was asked for a kiss by a young Caucasian boy upon parting from each other.

sen.j: 普仏戦争敗北と第二帝政の崩壊、かわって樹立された革命政府パリ・コミューンとドイツ軍によるその鎮圧という、混乱の真ただ中にパリに到着した西園寺は、以後10年近くにわたってフランスやヨーロッパの知識や思想、文化を吸収していった。
sen.e: SAIONJI, who arrived in Paris amidst the chaos of the defeat in the Franco-Prussian War, the fall of the Second Empire and the rise of The Revolution Government, the Paris Commune, in its stead and the suppression of it by the German forces, absorbed French and European knowledge, ideology and culture over almost the next 10 years.

SAIONJI, who arrived in Paris amidst the chaos of France's defeat in the Franco-Prussian War, the fall of the Second Empire, and the rise of The Revolution Government (the Paris Commune) in its stead, and the suppression of it by the German forces, absorbed French and European knowledge, ideology and culture over almost the next 10 years.
sen.cmt: changed to parenthetical statement because It was not at all clear that the revolutionary government WAS the Paris commune in trans 1.
sen.e: Saionji, who arrived in Paris amidst the chaos of France's defeat in the Franco-Prussian War, the fall of the Second Empire, and the rise of The Revolution Government (the Paris Commune) in its stead, and the suppression of it by the German forces, absorbed French and European knowledge, ideology and culture over almost the next 10 years.

sen.j: その間、後にフランス首相となるジョルジュ・クレマンソーや、留学生仲間の中江兆民、松田正久らと親交を結び、こうした人脈は帰国後も続いた。
sen.e: During this time, he became friends with Georges Clemenceau, who later became the Prime Minister of France, and the fellow scholars who came abroad to study, such as Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA, and their network continued even after he came back to Japan.

During this time, he became friends with Georges Clemenceau, who later became the Prime Minister of France, and fellow scholars who came abroad to study, such as Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA, with which network he continued even after he came back to Japan.
sen.cmt: deleted "the" their network --> with which network with whom might be better.
sen.e: During this time, he became friends with Georges Clemenceau, who later became the Prime Minister of France, and fellow scholars who came abroad to study, such as Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA, with which network he continued even after he came back to Japan.

sen.j: 西園寺はソルボンヌ大学で勉学にいそしむ一方で随分と遊蕩もしたようで、フランス人女性にもたいそう人気であったようである。
sen.e: SAIONJI, while he studied diligently at the Sorbonne he also engaged greatly in self-indulgence, and it also seems that he was quite popular among French women.
While SAIONJI studied diligently at the Sorbonne, he also engaged greatly in self-indulgence, and also it seems that he was quite popular among French women.
While Saionji studied diligently at the Sorbonne, he also engaged greatly in self-indulgence, and also it seems that he was quite popular among French women.

sen.j: なお、第一次世界大戦後のパリ講和会議（1919年）に日本の全権特使として出席した西園寺とパリ留学時代を同じ下宿ですごした親友クレマンソーとの友情は、講和会議での日本の立場を保持するのに大いに役立ったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that the friendship between SAIONJI, who attended the post World War I Paris Peace Conference (1919) as the envoy plenipotentiary of Japan, and his best friend Clemenceau, who stayed at the same boarding house as SAIONJI when he studied in Paris, was very instrumental in securing Japan's position at the Peace Conference.
sen.cmt: パリ講和会議 = Paris Peace Conference, 英辞郎 on the WEB; 全権特使 = Envoy plenipotentiary, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: It is said that the friendship between SAIONJI, who attended the post World War I Paris Peace Conference (1919) as the envoy plenipotentiary of Japan, and his best friend Clemenceau, who stayed at the same boarding house as SAIONJI when he studied in Paris, was very instrumental in securing Japan's position at the Peace Conference.

It is said that the friendship between Saionji, who attended the post World War I Paris Peace Conference (1919) as the envoy plenipotentiary of Japan, and his best friend Clemenceau, who stayed at the same boarding house as Saionji when he studied in Paris, was very instrumental in securing Japan's position at the Peace Conference.

sen.j: パリ留学で自由思想を学んだ西園寺は自由民権運動に傾倒し、明治14年（1881年）3月18日には、自由党結党に向けて創刊された『東洋自由新聞』の社長となり、中江兆民、松田正久らと共に発行に携わる。
sen.e: SAIONJI, who learned liberalism while he studied in Paris, became committed to Democratic Rights Movement, and on March 18, 1881, he became the president of "Toyo Jiyu Shinbun" journal company which was founded with the goal of establishing the Liberal Party, and he became involved in the publication along with Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA.

SAIONJI, who learned liberalism while he studied in Paris, became committed to Democratic Rights Movement, and on March 18, 1881, he became the president of "Toyo Jiyu Shinbun" journal company, which was founded with the goal of establishing the Liberal Party, and he became involved in its publications along with Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA.
sen.cmt: added a comma. the publication --> its publications.
sen.e: Saionji, who learned liberalism while he studied in Paris, became committed to Democratic Rights Movement, and on March 18, 1881, he became the president of "Toyo Jiyu Shinbun" journal company, which was founded with the goal of establishing the Liberal Party, and he became involved in its publications along with Chomin NAKAE and Masahisa MATSUDA.

sen.j: 西園寺が自由民権運動に加担することは政府や宮中で物議を呼び、内大臣岩倉具視が働きかけた明治天皇の内勅により退社を余儀なくされ、東洋自由新聞は4月30日発行の第34号にて廃刊に追い込まれた。
sen.e: SAIONJI's involvement in the Democratic Rights Movement became a controversy in the government as well as in the Imperial Court, and he was forced to resign from the company because of Emperor Meiji's private ordinance, that was set up by Minister of the Imperial Household, Tomomi IWAKURA, and Toyo Jiyu Shinbun was forced to shut down after publishing the 34th issue on April 30.

SAIONJI's involvement in the Democratic Rights Movement became controversial in the government as well as in the Imperial Court, and he was forced to resign from the company because of a private ordinance of Emperor Meiji's that was set up by Minister of the Imperial Household, Tomomi IWAKURA, and Toyo Jiyu Shinbun was forced to shut down after publishing the 34th issue on April 30.
sen.cmt: This would really be much better as 2 - 3 sentences, but at SunFlare's request I have left as is. Changed phrasing,
sen.e: Saionji's involvement in the Democratic Rights Movement became controversial in the government as well as in the Imperial Court, and he was forced to resign from the company because of a private ordinance of Emperor Meiji's that was set up by Minister of the Imperial Household, Tomomi IWAKURA, and Toyo Jiyu Shinbun was forced to shut down after publishing the 34th issue on April 30.

sen.j: この時の西園寺はあらゆる圧力に屈することはなかったが、明治天皇の内勅がでるとあっけないほど簡単に身をひいてしまった。
sen.e: During this time, SAIONJI never yielded to any pressure put on him, but when he received a private ordinance from Emperor Meiji he complied disappointingly quickly.
During this time, SAIONJI never yielded to any pressure put on him, but when he received a private ordinance from Emperor Meiji he complied disappointingly easily
During this time, Saionji never yielded to any pressure put on him, but when he received a private ordinance from Emperor Meiji he complied disappointingly easily

sen.j: この事件での彼の行動は彼の生涯にわたる世界観、政治観を端的にあらわしているともいえる。
sen.e: His actions in this incident plainly indicate his lifelong world view and political view.
Interestingly, the way he conducted himself throughout this affair plainly indicates his lifelong world view and political view.
sen.cmt: Added "interestingly" even though it is not in the Japanese. The sentence is much too abrupt without it. in this incident --> completely rephrased. This may border on iyaku, but I believe it to be a stronger sentence. Incident --> affair incident is too short. this was a longer lasting affair that ultimately culminated in the involvement of the emperor.
sen.e: Interestingly, the way he conducted himself throughout this affair plainly indicates his lifelong world view and political view.

sen.j: 西園寺はフランスで身に着けたリベラルな思想と名門公家の責務として皇室の藩屏たらねばならない意識というある意味で相反するものを共に有していた。
sen.e: In a way, SAIONJI had two conflicting views within him: the liberal thinking he acquired in France and his feeling of having to guard the wall of the Imperial family as the duty of his elite court noble family.

In a way, SAIONJI had two conflicting tendencies within him: the liberal thinking he acquired in France and his feeling of having to guard the honor of the Imperial family as the duty of his elite court noble family.
sen.cmt: wall --> honor. I do not know if honor is appropriate here, but wall is even worse.
sen.e: In a way, Saionji had two conflicting tendencies within him: the liberal thinking he acquired in France and his feeling of having to guard the honor of the Imperial family as the duty of his elite court noble family.

sen.j: そしてこの相反する二つを整理し融合したことから独特な世界観、政治観を持つ政治家へと成長した。
sen.e: Because he was able to reconcile and integrate these two conflicting views he developed into a politician with unique world and political views.
Because he was able to reconcile and integrate these two conflicting views, he developed into a politician with unique worldview and political ideology.
sen.cmt: worldview is the best word here, but say view twice is redundant, so I changed the second to ideology. Much more natural.
sen.e: Because he was able to reconcile and integrate these two conflicting views, he developed into a politician with unique worldview and political ideology.

sen.j: このことは時に彼を優柔不断に見せたが、後述する天皇への諫言は極めて適切であったといえ、こうしたところに西園寺の政治家としての真骨頂を感じられる。
sen.e: This made him look indecisive at times, but the words of admonishment he gave to the Emperor, which are mentioned later, were extremely appropriate, and SAIONJI's true worth as a politician can be felt through such actions.

This made him look indecisive at times, but the words of admonishment he gave to the Emperor, which are mentioned later, were extremely appropriate, and SAIONJI's true worth as a politician can be felt through such actions.

This made him look indecisive at times, but the words of admonishment he gave to the Emperor, which are mentioned later, were extremely appropriate, and Saionji's true worth as a politician can be felt through such actions.

sen.j: 西園寺のような感性をもった政治家を他に見出すことは難しい。
sen.e: It is difficult to find another politician with a sensibility like SAIONJI's.
Indeed, it is difficult to find another politician with a sensibility like SAIONJI's.
Indeed, it is difficult to find another politician with a sensibility like Saionji's.

sen.j: 生涯権力や金銭に対する執着は乏しく、この淡白な性質は上級公卿に生まれた育ちの良さからくるものであったと考えられる。
sen.e: He was poorly attached to power and money throughout his life, and this mellow personality of his can be considered to come from his birth as an elite court nobility with good upbringing.
He was but little attached to power and money throughout his life, and this mellow personality of his can be considered to come from his birth as a nobleman in an elite court with good upbringing.
sen.cmt: poorly attached --> meaning unclear. Changed to "but little attached" a.. Nobility --> X
sen.e: He was but little attached to power and money throughout his life, and this mellow personality of his can be considered to come from his birth as a nobleman in an elite court with good upbringing.

sen.j: この点で彼は終生の政敵山縣有朋とは対照的であった。
sen.e: On this point, he was a mirror opposite of his lifelong political enemy, Aritomo YAMAGATA.
On this point, he was the polar opposite of his lifelong political enemy, Aritomo YAMAGATA.
sen.cmt: a mirror opposite = unnatural the polar opposite --> very common idiom, but not colloquial.
sen.e: On this point, he was the polar opposite of his lifelong political enemy, Aritomo YAMAGATA.

sen.j: また、3人の内縁の妻を持ち、女子を儲けている一方、生涯正室は娶らなかった。
sen.e: While he had 3 wives, to whom he was not legally married, and had daughters, he never took an official wife.
Though he had 3 mistresses to whom he was not legally married, and had daughters, he never took an official wife.
sen.cmt: he had 3 wives although he had no wife --> X changed to mistresses. While --> although
sen.e: Although he had 3 mistresses to whom he was not legally married, and had daughters, he never took an official wife.

sen.j: はっきりした理由は西園寺自身述べていないが、名門西園寺家の当主であった彼は、娶るならば皇族、公家、大名家などの姫でなければならず、自由人であった西園寺がこうしたしがらみを嫌ったためとも言われている。
sen.e: SAIONJI himself never stated his clear reasons, but it is said that because he was the head of the elite SAIONJI family, if he were to marry his wife had to be a princess from an Imperial, a court noble or a major daimyo family, and SAIONJI, being a liberalist, disliked such constraints.

SAIONJI himself never stated his reasons for doing so clearly, but it is said that because he was the head of the elite SAIONJI family, if he were to marry, his wife would have to have been a princess from the Imperial family, a court noble, or from a major daimyo family, and SAIONJI, being a liberalist, disliked such constraints.
sen.cmt: would have to have been -->due to condition contrary to fact. Numerous minor changes.
sen.e: Saionji himself never stated his reasons for doing so clearly, but it is said that because he was the head of the elite Saionji family, if he were to marry, his wife would have to have been a princess from the Imperial family, a court noble, or from a major daimyo family, and Saionji, being a liberalist, disliked such constraints.

sen.j: 明治30年（1897年）、前年まで外務大臣を務めた陸奥宗光が、山縣を中心とする藩閥の打倒と議会制民主主義の未達成を嘆きつつ死んだ時、西園寺は「陸奥もとうとう冥土に往ってしまった。
sen.e: When Munemitsu MUTSU, who served as Minister of Foreign Affairs until the year before, died in 1897, lamenting the defeat of Han clique headed by YAMAGATA and the failure to establish parliamentary democracy, SAIONJI said, "even MUTSU finally went to the land of the dead.

When Munemitsu MUTSU (who had served as Minister of Foreign Affairs until the year before) died in 1897, SAIONJI said, "even MUTSU finally went to the land of the dead," lamenting the defeat of the Han clique headed by YAMAGATA and the failure to establish parliamentary democracy.
sen.cmt: Changed order of phrases, added parenthetical statement to simply the large number of commas. Is "clique" the best word ?
sen.e: When Munemitsu MUTSU (who had served as Minister of Foreign Affairs until the year before) died in 1897, Saionji said, 'even Mutsu finally went to the land of the dead,' lamenting the defeat of the Han clique headed by Yamagata and the failure to establish parliamentary democracy.

sen.j: 藩閥のやつらは、たたいても死にそうもないやつばかりだが」と言って、周囲の見る目も痛わしいほどに落胆したという。
sen.e: Those in Han clique were all people who looked like they would not die even if they were pounded," and he became so disappointed that it hurt those around him to see him lament.
Continuing, he said "Those in the Han clique were all people who looked like they would not die even if they were beaten and he became so disappointed that it hurt those around him to see him lament.
sen.cmt: changed structure to flow with previous sentence. Is "clique" appropriate terminology? Pounded -- > beaten
sen.e: Continuing, he said 'Those in the Han clique were all people who looked like they would not die even if they were beaten' and he became so disappointed that it hurt those around him to see him lament.

tit.j: 政治家としての西園寺

sen.j: 西園寺の政治家としてのキャリアは明治15年（1882年）、伊藤博文が憲法調査のためにヨーロッパを歴訪した際、それに随行したことにはじまる。
sen.e: SAIONJI's political career began when he accompanied Hirofumi ITO to visit Europe in order to study the constitution in 1882.
SAIONJI's political career began when he accompanied Hirofumi ITO to visit Europe in order to study the constitution in 1882.
Saionji's political career began when he accompanied Hirofumi ITO to visit Europe in order to study the constitution in 1882.

sen.j: 初入閣は明治27年（1894年）、第二次伊藤内閣の文部大臣としてであった。
sen.e: He became a cabinet member for the first time in 1894, as Minister of Education in the Second Ito Cabinet.
He became a cabinet member for the first time in 1894, as the Minister of Education in the Second Ito Cabinet.
He became a cabinet member for the first time in 1894, as the Minister of Education in the Second Ito Cabinet.

sen.j: ヨーロッパで伊藤の知遇を得た西園寺は、明治33年（1900年）の立憲政友会旗揚げに参画する。
sen.e: SAIONJI, whose talent was recognized by ITO in Europe, participated in the launching of Rikken Seiyu-kai Party in 1900.
SAIONJI, whose talent was recognized by ITO in Europe, participated in the launching of the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party in 1900.
Saionji, whose talent was recognized by Ito in Europe, participated in the launching of the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party in 1900.

sen.j: 明治36年（1903年）には伊藤の後を受けて総裁となり、明治39年（1906年）と明治44年（1911年）の2回にわたって内閣総理大臣に任命される。
sen.e: In 1903, he succeeded ITO as the Prime Minister, and he was assigned as the Prime Minister twice, in 1906 and in 1911.
In 1903, he succeeded ITO as the Prime Minister, and he was named Prime Minister twice, in 1906 and in 1911.
sen.cmt: Although I admit that I am not totally sure how their PMs came to power, I think it had to do with appointment by the emperor. That notwithstanding, I think "named" sounds better than "assigned" because named connotes accomplishment..
sen.e: In 1903, he succeeded Ito as the Prime Minister, and he was named Prime Minister twice, in 1906 and in 1911.

sen.j: 西園寺は思想的に自由主義を自称し、衆議院での多数派政党が内閣を組織する憲政の常道を慣例にした。
sen.e: SAIONJI ideologically proclaimed liberalism, and he established the constitutional practice of the majority party in the House of Representatives forming the Parliament.
SAIONJI ideologically proclaimed liberalism, and he established the constitutional practice of the majority party in the House of Representatives forming the Parliament.
Saionji ideologically proclaimed liberalism, and he established the constitutional practice of the majority party in the House of Representatives forming the Parliament.

sen.j: またフランス留学の影響からか親欧米的で、軍部などから国家主義に反する者として「世界主義者」と非難されることもあった。
sen.e: He was pro-Europe and pro-America due the influence he received while he studied in France, and he was called "globalist" and criticized by the military for being against nationalism.
sen.cmt: 「世界主義者」を用語集にある "cosmopolitan" から "globalist" に変更，出典：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: He was pro-Europe and pro-America due to the influence that studying in France had on him, and he was called a "globalist" and criticized by the military for being against nationalism.
sen.cmt: due --> due to. Rephrased the phrase: influence he received while he studied in France,
sen.e: He was pro-Europe and pro-America due to the influence that studying in France had on him, and he was called a 'globalist' and criticized by the military for being against nationalism.

sen.j: 西園寺は政治力がなかったという見方をされることが多いがこれは誤りで、山縣有朋の死去後政治力で彼を上回るものは当時の日本には存在しなくなった。
sen.e: SAIONJI is often viewed as having lacked political power, but this is wrong because after Aritomo YAMAGATA died nobody at the time surpassed him in terms of political power in Japan.
SAIONJI is often viewed as having lacked political power, however this is incorrect because, after Aritomo YAMAGATA died, there was no one surpassing him in terms of political power in Japan.
sen.cmt: but this is wrong --> too basic nobody --> no one
sen.e: Saionji is often viewed as having lacked political power, however this is incorrect because, after Aritomo YAMAGATA died, there was no one surpassing him in terms of political power in Japan.

sen.j: 宮中・財界との姻戚関係を背景に、彼は元老として宮中と国務、軍部の調整役を務め、日本の政治をリードし続けた。
sen.e: He continued to lead politics in Japan, using his family background in the Imperial Court as well as in the financial world, and mediating between the Imperial Court, national duties and the military as a Genro.

He continued to lead politics in Japan, using his family background in the Imperial Court as well as in the financial world, and mediating between the Imperial Court, national duties, and the military as a Genro.

He continued to lead politics in Japan, using his family background in the Imperial Court as well as in the financial world, and mediating between the Imperial Court, national duties, and the military as a Genro.

sen.j: また、文部大臣在任中に教育ニ関スル勅語の改訂を試みるなど昭和初期の国家主義的政治家とは一線を画す言動を散発的に見せるが、軍部の勢力拡大に抵抗したものの、彼だけの力では戦争回避を成し遂げることはできなかった。
sen.e: Furthermore, while he was Minister of Education he sporadically showed behavior that made a clear distinction between him and nationalistic politicians of the early Showa period, such as making an attempt at revising Ordinance on Education, but even though he resisted the expansion of military influence his power alone could not successfully prevent the war.

Furthermore, while he was Minister of Education he sporadically showed behavior that clearly distinguished him from nationalistic politicians of the early Showa period, such as making an attempt to revise the Ordinance on Education, but even though he resisted the expansion of military influence, his power alone could not successfully prevent the war.
sen.cmt: made a clear distinction between--> clearly distinguished him from as revising --> to revise; added "the" for proper noun. Commas.
sen.e: Furthermore, while he was Minister of Education he sporadically showed behavior that clearly distinguished him from nationalistic politicians of the early Showa period, such as making an attempt to revise the Ordinance on Education, but even though he resisted the expansion of military influence, his power alone could not successfully prevent the war.

sen.j: 西園寺は立命館大学に寄贈した扁額に「藤原公望」と西園寺家の本姓の藤原姓で名前を記したように、自らが千年以上皇室とともにあった藤原氏の末裔であるという自覚を持っていた。
sen.e: On the decorative frame he donated to Ritsumeikan University, he wrote his name as "Fujiwara no Kimmochi" using the surname of FUJIWARA, which makes it cleat that he was well-aware of being a descendant of Fujiwara clan that existed with the Imperial family for well over one thousand years.
sen.cmt: 扁額 = decorative frame, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: On the decorative frame he donated to Ritsumeikan University, he wrote his name as "Fujiwara no Kimmochi" using the surname FUJIWARA, which makes it clear that he was well-aware of being a descendant of the Fujiwara clan that existed with the Imperial family for well over one thousand years.
sen.cmt: cleat --> clear typo.. Commas added. Deleted "of" added the.
sen.e: On the decorative frame he donated to Ritsumeikan University, he wrote his name as 'Fujiwara no Kinmochi' using the surname Fujiwara, which makes it clear that he was well-aware of being a descendant of the Fujiwara clan that existed with the Imperial family for well over one thousand years.

sen.j: また、幼い頃から皇室に親しんでいたこともあって、「皇室の藩屏」という意識が強く、それが政治姿勢となっていた。
sen.e: Also, since he was familiar with the Imperial family since he was very young, he had a strong sense of "guarding the walls of the Imperial family", and that eventually became his political direction.
Also, since he was close to the Imperial family since he was very young, he had a strong sense of "guarding the walls of the Imperial family," and that eventually became his political direction.
sen.cmt: familiar with implies lower degree of friendship than close to. Comma inside quotation marks. Here we have the phrase "the walls of the imperial family" again, but this time it is in quotation marks so I left it.
sen.e: Also, since he was close to the Imperial family since he was very young, he had a strong sense of 'guarding the walls of the Imperial family,' and that eventually became his political direction.

sen.j: すなわち絶対的な権力を持つが故に誤謬が許されない天皇の親政に反対し続けた。
sen.e: That is, because possessing absolute political power would not tolerate any mistakes he continued to resist Imperial monarchy.
In other words, he continued to resist Imperial monarchy because errors are unacceptable when it comes to the possession of absolute political power.
sen.cmt: Complete rephrasing, the original was hard to understand.
sen.e: In other words, he continued to resist Imperial monarchy because errors are unacceptable when it comes to the possession of absolute political power.

sen.j: これは田中義一が張作霖爆殺事件（満州某重大事件）の上奏の不一致を昭和天皇に叱責され内閣が総辞職した際、西園寺が天皇に累を及ぼすということを口実にして、天皇による田中への叱責に反対していたことから見ても明らかである。
sen.e: This can be clearly seen from the fact that SAIONJI, using the excuse that it would cast a harmful effect on the Emperor, opposed the Emperor's reprimand of TANAKA when all the cabinet members resigned after Showa Emperor reprimanded Giichi TANAKA for the discord of Joso upon the Incident of Blowing Up Zhang Zuolin to Death (Certain Serious Incident in Manchuria).
sen.cmt: 張作霖爆殺事件（満州某重大事件） = Incident of blowing up Zhang Zuolin to death (Manchurian certain serious incident), 「定訳不明」
sen.e: This can be clearly seen from the fact that SAIONJI, using the excuse that it would cast a harmful effect on the Emperor, opposed the Emperor's reprimand of TANAKA when all the cabinet members resigned after Showa Emperor reprimanded Giichi TANAKA for the discord of Joso upon the Incident of Blowing Up Zhang Zuolin to Death (a certain serious incident in Manchuria).
sen.cmt: IMPORTANT: should SHOWA be capitalized? Consider switiching showa emperor to emperor showa. Also, "the Incident of Blowing Up Zhang Zuolin to Death" is "yougo" but it is clearly bad phrasing and should be changed. It is unnatural and redundant (blowing up always = death). uncapitalized the parenthetical words.
sen.e: This can be clearly seen from the fact that Saionji, using the excuse that it would cast a harmful effect on the Emperor, opposed the Emperor's reprimand of Tanaka when all the cabinet members resigned after Showa Emperor reprimanded Giichi TANAKA for the discord of Joso upon the Incident of Blowing Up Zhang Zuolin to Death (a certain serious incident in Manchuria).
sen.cmt: SAIONJI→Saionjiスペース削除TANAKA→TanakaShowa Emperor→Emperor Showa

sen.j: また、「立憲君主として、臣下の決定に反対しない」という昭和天皇の信条は西園寺の影響とする向きもある。
sen.e: Also, Showa Emperor's principle of "as a constitutional monarch, I will not oppose the decisions made by my subjects" is said to have been influenced by SAIONJI.
Also, Showa Emperor's pledge that "as a constitutional monarch, I will not oppose the decisions made by my subjects" is said to have been influenced by SAIONJI.
Also, Emperor Showa's pledge that 'as a constitutional monarch, I will not oppose the decisions made by my subjects' is said to have been influenced by Saionji.
sen.cmt: SAIONJI→Saionji原文の「」に合わせ"を'にShowa Emperor→Emperor Showa

sen.j: しかしながらこの姿勢は一方で、皇道派将校の反感をも招いた。
sen.e: However, on the other hand, this attitude invited antagonism among the officers of Imperial Way Party.
However, on the other hand, this attitude invited antagonism with the officers of Imperial Way Party.
However, on the other hand, this attitude invited antagonism with the officers of Imperial Way Party.

tit.e: Kei-En (Katsura-Saionji) Era and Taisho Political Change
The Kei-En (Katsura-Saionji) Era and Taisho Political Change
tit.cmt: I lack context, but there might be a better way to phrase: Taisho Political Change adddd "the"
tit.e: The Kei-En (Katsura-Saionji) Era and Taisho Political Change

sen.j: 明治39年（1906年）には桂太郎の後を受けて第1次西園寺内閣を組織。
sen.e: In 1906, he succeeded Taro KATSURA and formed the First SAIONJI Cabinet.
In 1906, he succeeded Taro KATSURA and formed the First SAIONJI Cabinet.
In 1906, he succeeded Taro KATSURA and formed the First Saionji Cabinet.

sen.j: そののち再び桂が総理となり、桂・西園寺会談での「情意投合」によって明治44年（1911年）には第2次西園寺内閣を組織した。
sen.e: After that, KATUSRA again became the Prime Minister, and by the "agreement of feelings and intentions" reached during the KATSURA-SAIONJI meeting the Second SAIONJI Cabinet was formed in 1911.
After that, KATSURA again became the Prime Minister, and by the "agreement of feelings and intentions" reached during the KATSURA-SAIONJI meeting, the Second SAIONJI Cabinet was formed in 1911.
After that, Katsura again became the Prime Minister, and by the 'agreement of feelings and intentions' reached during the Katsura-Saionji meeting, the Second Saionji Cabinet was formed in 1911.

sen.j: 桂と西園寺が交互に総理を務めたこの時代を桂園時代という。
sen.e: This period in which KATUSRA and SAIONJI alternately served as the Prime Minister is called the Kei-En Era.
This period in which KATSURA and SAIONJI alternately served as the Prime Minister is called the Kei-En Era.
This period in which Katsura and Saionji alternately served as the Prime Minister is called the Kei-En Era.

sen.j: 政友会の幹部は桂との対抗関係を強調し、西園寺も表向きはその姿勢を見せていたが、桂に「君と僕とにて国家を背負ふて立とうではないか」と言うほどポスト元老世代である2人の政治的な関係は良好であった。
sen.e: The executive staff of Seiyu-kai Party emphasized rivalry and SAIONJI also showed such stance the on the surface, but he said to KATSURA, "let you and I stand up and lead the nation," and there was a good political relationship between the two who both belonged to the post-Genro generation.

The executive staff of Seiyu-kai Party emphasized their rivalry, and on the surface SAIONJI maintained such a position, but he also said to KATSURA, "let you and I stand up and lead the nation," and there was a good political relationship between the two who both belonged to the post-Genro generation.
sen.cmt: several additions to smoothen the diction. Added "their" stance --> position.
sen.e: The executive staff of Seiyu-kai Party emphasized their rivalry, and on the surface Saionji maintained such a position, but he also said to Katsura, 'let you and I stand up and lead the nation,' and there was a good political relationship between the two who both belonged to the post-Genro generation.

sen.j: また、愛妾を同伴し酒を酌み交わすなど「蕩児」としての共通部分もあったようである。
sen.e: They also seemed to have shared the characteristic of being "prodigals," drinking together with their concubines.
They also seemed to have shared the trait of being "prodigals," drinking together with their concubines.
They also seemed to have shared the trait of being 'prodigals,' drinking together with their concubines.

sen.j: 第2次西園寺内閣は基盤とする与党立憲政友会が衆議院で絶対多数を占めたこともあり、行財政改革に着手した。
sen.e: The Second SAIONJI Cabinet began the administrative and financial reform because the ruling party, Rikken Seiyu-kai Party, that formed the foundation of the cabient, won an absolute majority in the House of Representatives.

The Second SAIONJI Cabinet began the administrative and financial reform because the ruling party (the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party) that formed the foundation of the cabinet won an absolute majority in the House of Representatives.
sen.cmt: added "the." cabient --> cabinet (typo) added parentheses removed commas
sen.e: The Second Saionji Cabinet began the administrative and financial reform because the ruling party (the Rikken Seiyu-kai Party) that formed the foundation of the cabinet won an absolute majority in the House of Representatives.

sen.j: 大正2年（1913年）の予算策定に向けて歳出1割減を目標としたが、大日本帝国陸軍は2個師団の増設を要求し、大日本帝国海軍もまた戦艦3隻建造を予算案に盛り込んだ。
sen.e: Upon drafting the budget for 1913 he aimed to reduce spending by 10%, but the Imperial Japan Army demanded addition of 2 military divisions, and the Imperial Japan Navy also added construction of 3 battleships in the budget proposal.

His draft of the budget for 1913 aimed to reduce spending by 10%, but the Imperial Japan Army demanded the addition of two military divisions, and the Imperial Japan Navy also added construction of three battleships in the budget proposal.

His draft of the budget for 1913 aimed to reduce spending by 10%, but the Imperial Japan Army demanded the addition of two military divisions, and the Imperial Japan Navy also added construction of three battleships in the budget proposal.

sen.j: 陸軍は西園寺内閣を倒してでも2個師団増設を達成すべく奔走し、内閣があくまでも拒否との方針を示すと、上原勇作陸軍省陸軍大臣は天皇に直接辞表を提出した。
sen.e: The Army exerted themselves in order to succeed in adding 2 military divisions even if that meant overpowering SAIONJI Cabinet, and when the cabinet indicated unyielding refusal Yusaku UEHARA, Minister of Army at Ministry of Army submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.

The Army exerted itself in order to succeed in adding two military divisions even if that meant overpowering the SAIONJI Cabinet, but when the cabinet indicated an absolute refusal, Yusaku UEHARA, the Minister of the Army at the Ministry of the Army submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.
sen.cmt: army --> it minor stylistic changes added "the" several times, even to proper noun phrases, please verify these additions.
sen.e: The Army exerted itself in order to succeed in adding two military divisions even if that meant overpowering the Saionji Cabinet, but when the cabinet indicated an absolute refusal, Yusaku UEHARA, the Minister of the Army at the Ministry of the Army submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.

sen.j: 陸軍大臣には直接天皇に上奏する帷幄上奏が制度上認められてはいたが、閣僚が首相を通さずに直接天皇に辞表を提出したのは前代未聞のことであった。
sen.e: Even though Minister of Army was allowed, in principle, to state his intentions directly to the Emperor, known as iaku-joso (to make comments on military affairs to the Emperor with full responsibility of the results), but this was the very first time a cabinet member bypassed the Prime Minister and submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.

Even though the Minister of Army was allowed, in principle, to state his intentions directly to the Emperor, a power known as iaku-joso (to make comments on military affairs to the Emperor with full responsibility for the results), in reality this was the very first time a cabinet member bypassed the Prime Minister and submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.
sen.cmt: several minor changes, most important added "a power" and changed but --> in reality
sen.e: Even though the Minister of Army was allowed, in principle, to state his intentions directly to the Emperor, a power known as iaku-joso (to make comments on military affairs to the Emperor with full responsibility for the results), in reality this was the very first time a cabinet member bypassed the Prime Minister and submitted a letter of resignation directly to the Emperor.

sen.j: また、陸軍が後任の陸相を送らない限り、西園寺内閣は軍部大臣現役武官制の規定によって陸相が得られないこととなって辞職するよりほかなかった。
sen.e: Also, unless the Army sent the succeeding army officer, according to the rules of Military ministers to be officers on active-duty, the SAIONJI Cabinet was unable to obtain a military officer, and he was given no other choice but to resign.

Also, unless the Army appointed a succeeding officer, according to the rules of Military ministers who were officers on active-duty, the SAIONJI Cabinet was unable to obtain a military officer, and SAIONJI was given no other choice but to resign.
sen.cmt: sent --> appointed (consider selected as well) IMPORTANT I think that this (and he was given no other choice but to resign.) means SAIONJI. However as always the subject is not restated in the Japanese. But if it is not SAIONJI, then please correct my changes
sen.e: Also, unless the Army appointed a succeeding officer, according to the rules of Military ministers who were officers on active-duty, the Saionji Cabinet was unable to obtain a military officer, and Saionji was given no other choice but to resign.

sen.j: 当時、陸相辞任の影響は非常に大きかったのである。
sen.e: At the time, the effect of the resignation of Minister of Army was very large.
Thus, at that time, the effect of the resignation of the Minister of the Army was very large.
sen.cmt: At the time, --> Thus, at that time,
sen.e: Thus, at that time, the effect of the resignation of the Minister of the Army was very large.

sen.j: 西園寺は、この後大正天皇に呼び出され、天皇の口から直接陸相の辞表提出の件を知らされた。
sen.e: SAIONJI was later summoned by Emperor Taisho, and he was told directly by the Emperor's mouth about the Minister of Army's submission of letter of resignation.
SAIONJI was later summoned by Emperor Taisho, and he was told by the Emperor directly about the Minister of Army's submission of his letter of resignation.
Saionji was later summoned by Emperor Taisho, and he was told by the Emperor directly about the Minister of Army's submission of his letter of resignation.

sen.j: 西園寺は、後任の陸相について陸軍の実力者山縣有朋にも相談したが、山県が後任の陸相を出す気がないことを察すると、機先を制して内閣総辞職した。
sen.e: SAIONJI consulted with Aritomo YAMAGATA, who was an influential figure in the Army, about the succeeding Army officer, but once he figured out that YAMAGATA had no intention of recommending the succeeding Army officer he took a preemptive measure of having all the cabinet members resign.

SAIONJI consulted with Aritomo YAMAGATA, who was an influential figure in the Army, about the succeeding Army officer, but once he figured out that YAMAGATA had no intention of recommending a succeeding Army officer SAIONJI took the preemptive measure of having all the cabinet members resign.
sen.cmt: the <--> a restated SAIONJI to avoid ambiguity.
sen.e: Saionji consulted with Aritomo YAMAGATA, who was an influential figure in the Army, about the succeeding Army officer, but once he figured out that Yamagata had no intention of recommending a succeeding Army officer Saionji took the preemptive measure of having all the cabinet members resign.

sen.j: 政友会を通じて内閣総辞職の内幕が知れ渡ると国民の間ににわかに「閥族打破、憲政擁護」の気運が高まり護憲運動となった。
sen.e: Once the inside story of the resignation of all the cabinet members was leaked out and spread through Seiyu-kai Party, the sentiment of "destroy the clique families, protect politics by the constitution" suddenly gained momentum among the citizens, and the constitution protection movement started.
sen.cmt: 閥族打破 = clique families, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: Once the story from inside the cabinet of the resignation of all the cabinet members was leaked out and spread through Seiyu-kai Party, the sentiment to "destroy the clique families, protect politics by the constitution" suddenly gained momentum among the citizenry, and the constitution protection movement started.
sen.cmt: added "from inside the cabinet" to make it sound better. Of--> to citizens-->citizenry Does this movement have a specific name? Is that it? Then it should be capitalized…
sen.e: Once the story from inside the cabinet of the resignation of all the cabinet members was leaked out and spread through Seiyu-kai Party, the sentiment to 'destroy the clique families, protect politics by the constitution' suddenly gained momentum among the citizenry, and the constitution protection movement started.

sen.j: 政友会は立憲国民党の犬養毅らと提携し、護憲運動の陣頭に立ち、西園寺内閣の後任の第3次桂内閣と対立した。
sen.e: Seiyu-kai Party formed an alliance with Tsuyoshi INUKAI of Rikken (Constitutional) National Party, led the movement to protect the constitution and confronted the Third Katsura Cabinet that succeeded the SAIONJI cabinet.

The Seiyu-kai Party formed an alliance with Tsuyoshi INUKAI of the Rikken (Constitutional) National Party, led the movement to protect the constitution, and confronted the Third Katsura Cabinet that succeeded the SAIONJI cabinet.

The Seiyu-kai Party formed an alliance with Tsuyoshi INUKAI of the Rikken (Constitutional) National Party, led the movement to protect the constitution, and confronted the Third Katsura Cabinet that succeeded the Saionji cabinet.

sen.j: ただし、政国提携や国民に向けた演説会などには西園寺は直接タッチしておらず、これらは政友会の幹部である原敬や松田正久、政友会会員尾崎行雄、国民党の犬養毅らが中心となっていた。
sen.e: However, SAIONJI was not directly involved in the Sei-Koku alliance (Seiyu-kai Party-National Party alliance) or the campaign speeches aimed at the citizens, and senior members of Seiyu-kai Party, such as Takashi HARA and Masahisa MATSUDA, Yukio OZAKI, a member of Seiyu-kai Party, and Tsuyoshi INUKAI of National Party played the central role in these.

However, SAIONJI was not directly involved in the Sei-Koku alliance (Seiyu-kai Party-National Party alliance) or the campaign speeches aimed at the citizens, and senior members of Seiyu-kai Party, such as Takashi HARA and Masahisa MATSUDA, Yukio OZAKI, a member of Seiyu-kai Party, and Tsuyoshi INUKAI of National Party played central roles in these events.

However, Saionji was not directly involved in the Sei-Koku alliance (Seiyu-kai Party-National Party alliance) or the campaign speeches aimed at the citizens, and senior members of Seiyu-kai Party, such as Takashi HARA and Masahisa MATSUDA, Yukio OZAKI, a member of Seiyu-kai Party, and Tsuyoshi INUKAI of National Party played central roles in these events.

sen.j: 議会はもともと政友会が絶対多数であったので、議会が開始されると政友会・国民党は内閣不信任案を提出し桂内閣は窮地に立たされた。
sen.e: Seiyu-kai Party had the absolute majority in the House of Representatives to begin with, so when the Parliament convened Seiyu-kai Party and National Party submitted a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, and Katsura Cabinet was beleaguered.

Seiyu-kai Party had the absolute majority in the House of Representatives to begin with, so when the Parliament convened, the Seiyu-kai Party and National Party submitted a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, and this applied pressure to the Katsura Cabinet.

Seiyu-kai Party had the absolute majority in the House of Representatives to begin with, so when the Parliament convened, the Seiyu-kai Party and National Party submitted a motion of no confidence in the Cabinet, and this applied pressure to the Katsura Cabinet.

sen.j: そこで政府側では、イギリスのジョージ5世 (イギリス王)即位の際、即位直後であることを理由に自由党 (イギリス)と保守党 (イギリス)との政争をやめるよう命令して、それを実現させた話にならい、ちょうど大正天皇が即位して間もない頃だったので、勅語を出すという形で西園寺公望に対し政争を中止するように諭した。
sen.e: Following the story of how the end of the political battle was realized because of the order that was given to stop the political battle between the Liberal Party (Britain) and the Conservative Party (Britain) using the coronation of George V (King of Britain) as a reason, the government advised, in the form of Emperor's ordinance, Kimmochi SAIONJI to stop the political battle since Emperor Taisho had just been enthroned as the Emperor.

Following the story of how the end of the political battle was realized because of the order that was given to stop the political battle between the Liberal Party (Britain) and the Conservative Party (Britain) using the coronation of George V (King of Britain) as a reason, the government advised, in the form of an ordinance of the Emperor, Kimmochi SAIONJI to stop the political battle since Emperor Taisho had just been enthroned as the Emperor.
sen.cmt: consider changing reason to "pretext" minor rephrasing IMPORTANT above we have Showa emperor, but here we have Emperor Taisho, the opposite phrasing. This should be made consistent.
sen.e: Following the story of how the end of the political battle was realized because of the order that was given to stop the political battle between the Liberal Party (Britain) and the Conservative Party (Britain) using the coronation of George, the 5th (King of Britain) as a reason, the government advised, in the form of an ordinance of the Emperor, Kinmochi SAIONJI to stop the political battle since Emperor Taisho had just been enthroned as the Emperor.

sen.j: 政友会では天皇の意思であるならそれに従うよりほかはないと、不信任案を撤回して、ひとまずは桂内閣に貸しを作ろうという意見が一時有力になった。
sen.e: A dominant opinion temporarily formed within Seiyu-kai Party that there was no other option than to comply with the Emperor's wish, and they withdrew the motion of no confidence so that for the time being they did Katsura Cabinet a favor.

A dominant opinion temporarily formed within the Seiyu-kai Party that there was no other option than to comply with the Emperor's wish, and they withdrew the motion of no confidence so that for a short time the Katsura Cabinet was indebted to them.
sen.cmt: for the time being --> For a short time / did a favor --> was indebted
sen.e: A dominant opinion temporarily formed within the Seiyu-kai Party that there was no other option than to comply with the Emperor's wish, and they withdrew the motion of no confidence so that for a short time the Katsura Cabinet was indebted to them.

sen.j: しかし、これに政友会会員尾崎行雄が強行に反発した。
sen.e: However, Yukio OZAKI, a Seiyu-kai Party member, strongly opposed to this idea.
However, Yukio OZAKI, a Seiyu-kai Party member, strongly opposed this idea.
However, Yukio OZAKI, a Seiyu-kai Party member, strongly opposed this idea.

sen.j: それに対して西園寺は前述のように「天皇の藩屏」としての誇りと政友会総裁としての責任の間で板挟みとなってしまう。
sen.e: On the other hand, SAIONJI, as mentioned earlier, was torn between his pride of "guarding the walls of the Imperial family" and the responsibility as the head of the Seiyu-kai Party.
On the other hand, SAIONJI, as mentioned earlier, was torn between his desire to "guard the walls of the Imperial family" and his responsibility as the head of the Seiyu-kai Party.
sen.cmt: pride of --> desire to the--> his
sen.e: On the other hand, Saionji, as mentioned earlier, was torn between his desire to 'guard the walls of the Imperial family' and his responsibility as the head of the Seiyu-kai Party.

sen.j: そして、犬養毅の助言で西園寺は政友会総裁を辞任し、政友会自体はあくまでも内閣退陣を要求するということになった。
sen.e: On the advice of Tsuyoshi INUKAI, SAIONJI resigned from the head of Seiyu-kai Party, so that the sole request by Seiyu-kai Party itself was withdraw of the cabinet.
On the advice of Tsuyoshi INUKAI, SAIONJI resigned from the head of Seiyu-kai Party, so that the withdraw of the cabinet was requested by the Seiyu-kai Party alone.
On the advice of Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Saionji resigned from the head of Seiyu-kai Party, so that the withdraw of the cabinet was requested by the Seiyu-kai Party alone.

sen.j: このとき、海軍の山本権兵衛が政友会本部を激励のために訪れている。
sen.e: At this time, Gombei YAMAMOTO of the Navy visited the Seiyu-kai Party headquarter to give them encouragement.
At this time, Gombei YAMAMOTO of the Navy visited the Seiyu-kai Party headquarters to encourage them.
At this time, Gonbei YAMAMOTO of the Navy visited the Seiyu-kai Party headquarters to encourage them.

sen.j: 結局、護憲運動の高まりで桂内閣は大正2年2月11日に辞意を表明した（大正政変）。
sen.e: In the end, because of the heightening of the movement to protect the constitution, Katsura Cabinet announced resignation on February 11, 1913 (Taisho Political Change).
In the end, because of the strengthening of the movement to protect the constitution, the Katsura Cabinet announced its resignation on February 11, 1913 (Taisho Political Change).
sen.cmt: heightening-->strengthening in this case strengthening is better added "the" "its"
sen.e: In the end, because of the strengthening of the movement to protect the constitution, the Katsura Cabinet announced its resignation on February 11, 1913 (Taisho Political Change).

sen.j: 同日後継首相を決めるための元老会議が開かれた。
sen.e: On the same day, a council of Genro was held in order to pick the succeeding Prime Minister.
On the same day, a council of Genro was held in order to pick the succeeding Prime Minister.
On the same day, a council of Genro was held in order to pick the succeeding Prime Minister.

sen.j: このときの会議には西園寺もはじめて元老として出席した。
sen.e: At this time, SAIONJI also attended the meeting as a Genro for the first time.
At this time, SAIONJI also attended the meeting as a Genro for the first time.
At this time, Saionji also attended the meeting as a Genro for the first time.

sen.j: しかし、政友会の代表としての出席ではなかった。
sen.e: However, he did not attend as a representative of Seiyu-kai Party.
However, he did not attend as a representative of the Seiyu-kai Party.
However, he did not attend as a representative of the Seiyu-kai Party.

sen.j: 会議では、最初に西園寺が後継首相に推薦されたが、これを受ければ勅語に反することになるとして西園寺は固辞した。
sen.e: During the meeting, at first, SAIONJI was recommended as the succeeding Prime Minister, but SAIONJI firmly declined because accepting this would betray the Ordinance.
During the meeting, at first, SAIONJI was recommended as the succeeding Prime Minister, but SAIONJI firmly declined because accepting this recommendation would betray the Ordinance.
During the meeting, at first, Saionji was recommended as the succeeding Prime Minister, but Saionji firmly declined because accepting this recommendation would betray the Ordinance.

sen.j: 結局、後継首相には山本権兵衛が決まった。
sen.e: In the end, Gombei YAMAMOTO was selected to be the succeeding Prime Minister.
In the end, Gombei YAMAMOTO was selected to be the succeeding Prime Minister.
In the end, Gonbei YAMAMOTO was selected to be the succeeding Prime Minister.

sen.j: 一連の処理が終わると、西園寺は改めて先の大正天皇からの勅語に違反した「違勅」の罪を理由に政友会総裁の辞任を表明した。
sen.e: Once the aftermath related to this incident was dealt with, SAIONJI announced his resignation from the head of Seiyu-kai Party for the first time, using the charge of "Violation of the Ordinance".
Once the aftermath related to this incident was dealt with, SAIONJI announced his resignation as the head of the Seiyu-kai Party for the first time, citing the charge of "Violation of the Ordinance."
Once the aftermath related to this incident was dealt with, Saionji announced his resignation as the head of the Seiyu-kai Party for the first time, citing the charge of 'Violation of the Ordinance.'

sen.j: 「違勅」は近代法においては存在しないが、「天皇の藩屏」である事を第一としていた伝統的な公家社会においては最も重い罪の1つであった。
sen.e: Even though "Violation of the Ordinance" does not exist in the modern law, this was one of the most serious crimes in the society of court nobles that placed the highest value on "guarding the walls of the Imperial Family."

Even though the charge of "Violation of the Ordinance" does not exist in the modern law, this was one of the most serious crimes in the society of court nobles, which placed the highest value on "guarding the walls of the Imperial Family."

Even though the charge of 'Violation of the Ordinance' does not exist in the modern law, this was one of the most serious crimes in the society of court nobles, which placed the highest value on 'guarding the walls of the Imperial Family.'

sen.j: また、第2次内閣時代には政友会内部を掌握し、鉄道建設など地方利益の追求に熱心であった原との間に確執が生じており、総裁辞任のため「違勅」を利用したのである。
sen.e: He also used "Violation of the Ordinance" as an excuse to resign from his position as the head because during the era of the Second Cabinet he developed a conflict between HARA, who took over the inside of the Seiyu-kai Party and who was eagerly seeking local profit through railroad constructions.

He also used the charge of "Violation of the Ordinance" as a pretext to resign from his position as the head because, during the era of the Second Cabinet, he had had a conflict with HARA, who took over the inside of the Seiyu-kai Party and who was eagerly seeking profit through railroad constructions in the countryside.
sen.cmt: added "the charge of" excuse --> pretext. Local -> in the countryside developed --> had had
sen.e: He also used the charge of 'Violation of the Ordinance' as a pretext to resign from his position as the head because, during the era of the Second Cabinet, he had had a conflict with Hara, who took over the inside of the Seiyu-kai Party and who was eagerly seeking profit through railroad constructions in the countryside.

sen.j: 政友会の幹部達はこの「違勅」の論理に困惑して西園寺を慰留したが、西園寺の決意は揺らぐことは無かった。
sen.e: The executive members of Seiyu-kai Party were befuddled by this logic of "Violation of the Ordinance" and they tried to dissuade SAIONJI, but SAIONJI's determination never wavered.
The executive members of the Seiyu-kai Party were befuddled by this logic of citing a "Violation of the Ordinance" and they tried to dissuade SAIONJI, but SAIONJI's determination never wavered.
The executive members of the Seiyu-kai Party were befuddled by this logic of citing a 'Violation of the Ordinance' and they tried to dissuade Saionji, but Saionji's determination never wavered.

sen.j: 昭和
sen.e: Showa
Showa
Showa

sen.j: 西園寺は明治の元勲に一世代遅れて、大正天皇即位のときに元老に列せられている。
sen.e: SAIONJI was not listed in Genkun (oligarch with merit) of Meiji, but as a Genro one generation later when Emperor Taisho was enthroned.
SAIONJI was not listed as a Genkun (oligarch with merit) of Meiji, but as a Genro one generation later when Emperor Taisho was enthroned.
Saionji was not listed as a Genkun (oligarch with merit) of Meiji, but as a Genro one generation later when Emperor Taisho was enthroned.

sen.j: これを最後にあらたな元老が指名されることはついになく、大正13年（1924年）に松方正義が死去すると西園寺が唯一人の元老となった。
sen.e: With this marking the last time, new Genro has never been appointed since, and when Masayoshi MATSUKATA passed away in 1924, SAIONJI became the only Genro.
This being the last time, a new Genro has never been appointed since, and when Masayoshi MATSUKATA passed away in 1924, SAIONJI became the only Genro.
This being the last time, a new Genro has never been appointed since, and when Masayoshi MATSUKATA passed away in 1924, Saionji became the only Genro.

sen.j: これ以後、内閣総理大臣奏薦は西園寺が内大臣府との協議により行うこととなった。
sen.e: After this, advising of the appointment of the prime minister was conducted by negotiations between SAIONJI and Minister of Imperial Household.
sen.cmt: 内閣総理大臣奏薦 = advising the appointment of the prime minister
sen.e: After this, advising of the appointment of the prime minister was conducted by negotiations between SAIONJI and the Minister of Imperial Household.
After this, advising of the appointment of the prime minister was conducted by negotiations between SAIONJI and the Minister of Imperial Household.

sen.j: 昭和元年（1926年）12月28日、践祚直後の昭和天皇は西園寺に対し特に勅語を与え（「大勲位公爵西園寺公望ニ賜ヒタル勅語」）、これにより、西園寺は「最後の元老」として引き続き内閣総理大臣奏薦の任に当たることが制度上確定、昭和15年（1940年）1月の米内内閣までは何らかの形で首班推奏に関与し続けることになる（第二次近衛内閣については奏薦を謝絶している）。
sen.e: On December 28, 1926, Emperor Showa, who had just been enthroned, gave an ordinance to SAIONJI in particular ("Ordinance given to the Supreme Order Prince Kimmochi SAIONJI"), and by this, it became institutionally certain for SAIONJI to be "the last Genro" and to continue serving as an advisor regarding the appointment of the Prime Minister, and he continued in one way or another to be involved in the recommendation of the Cabinet Chief until Yonai Cabinet was formed in January, 1940 (he declined to give recommendations to the Second Konoe cabinet).

On December 28, 1926, Emperor Showa, who had just been enthroned, issued an ordinance to SAIONJI in particular ("Ordinance given to the Supreme Order Prince Kimmochi SAIONJI"), and by this, it became institutionally certain for SAIONJI to be "the last Genro" and to continue serving as an advisor regarding the appointment of the Prime Minister, and he continued in one way or another to be involved in the recommendations of the Cabinet Chiefs until the Yonai Cabinet was formed in January, 1940 (he declined to give recommendations to the Second Konoe cabinet).
sen.cmt: gave --> issued added s to cabinet and chief. IMPORTANT consider changing the wording of "institutionally certain"
sen.e: On December 28, 1926, Emperor Showa, who had just been enthroned, issued an ordinance to Saionji in particular ('Ordinance given to the Supreme Order Prince Kinmochi SAIONJI'), and by this, it became institutionally certain for Saionji to be 'the last Genro' and to continue serving as an advisor regarding the appointment of the Prime Minister, and he continued in one way or another to be involved in the recommendations of the Cabinet Chiefs until the Yonai Cabinet was formed in January, 1940 (he declined to give recommendations to the Second Konoe cabinet).

sen.j: 昭和3年（1928年）、張作霖爆殺事件（満州某重大事件）では事件の顛末の報告に対し、最初に不審を抱いたのが西園寺であった。
sen.e: At the Incident of blowing up Zhang Zuolin to death (Manchurian certain serious incident) in 1928, SAIONJI was the first person to become suspicious when the full account of the incident was reported.
sen.cmt: 張作霖爆殺事件（満州某重大事件） = Incident of blowing up Zhang Zuolin to death (Manchurian certain serious incident), 「定訳不明」
sen.e: Regarding the Incident of blowing up Zhang Zuolin to death (Manchurian certain serious incident) in 1928, SAIONJI was the first person to become suspicious when the full account of the incident was reported.
sen.cmt: at --> regarding. Again, I would change the "yougo" here
sen.e: Regarding the Incident of blowing up Zhang Zuolin to death (Manchurian certain serious incident) in 1928, Saionji was the first person to become suspicious when the full account of the incident was reported.

sen.j: 西園寺は陸軍の仕業であることに気づき、興津より上京して首相田中義一を呼びつけ、政府としてこの問題をしっかり調べ、もし犯人が日本人であるならば厳罰に処す必要があることを申し渡している。
sen.e: SAIONJI noticed that the Army had a hand in this, and he came to the capital from Okitsu, summoned Prime Minister Giichi TANAKA, and advised that the government must thoroughly investigate this problem, and if the guilty party was Japanese a harsh punishment would then be necessary.

SAIONJI suspected that the Army had a hand in the incident, and went to the capital from Okitsu, summoned Prime Minister Giichi TANAKA, and advised him that the government must thoroughly investigate this affair, and if the guilty party was Japanese, a harsh punishment should be exacted.
sen.cmt: I changed the phrasing substantially, I think it is much more fluid and cogent now.
sen.e: Saionji suspected that the Army had a hand in the incident, and went to the capital from Okitsu, summoned Prime Minister Giichi TANAKA, and advised him that the government must thoroughly investigate this affair, and if the guilty party was Japanese, a harsh punishment should be exacted.

sen.j: この件に関して田中も、国際的な信用を保つために容疑者を軍法会議によって厳罰に処すべきとの考えを示したが、一向に実行にいたらないので西園寺は再び調査と報告を急かしている。
sen.e: Regarding this incident, TANAKA also indicated his view of harshly punishing the suspect in the court-martial so as to maintain international credibility, but because nothing was being done SAIONJI again urged the investigation and the report.

Regarding this incident, TANAKA also indicated his view of harshly punishing the perpetrator via court-martial so as to maintain international credibility, but because nothing was being done SAIONJI again urged the investigation and the report.
sen.cmt: suspects are not punished (hopefully) guilty parties are. In the --> via
sen.e: Regarding this incident, Tanaka also indicated his view of harshly punishing the perpetrator via court-martial so as to maintain international credibility, but because nothing was being done Saionji again urged the investigation and the report.

sen.j: そのいっぽうで、昭和天皇が田中を「もう田中の話は聞きたくない」と叱責したことについては、立憲君主制の立場からすればふさわしくないとして、天皇を諫めている。
sen.e: On the other hand, he admonished the Emperor for not behaving appropriately as a constitutional monarch when Emperor Showa admonished TANAKA saying, "I don't want to hear any more from TANAKA."
On the other hand, he admonished the Emperor for not behaving appropriately (as a constitutional monarch) when Emperor Showa admonished TANAKA saying, "I don't want to hear any more from TANAKA."
On the other hand, he admonished the Emperor for not behaving appropriately (as a constitutional monarch) when Emperor Showa admonished Tanaka saying, 'I don't want to hear any more from Tanaka.'

sen.j: 昭和11年（1936年）の二・二六事件事件においては、決起将校の一部が西園寺襲撃を計画していたが、実行されなかった。
sen.e: At the February 26 Incident of 1936, a part of (resolutely) Mutinied Officers had planned to attack SAIONJI, but it was never put into action.
In the February 26 Incident of 1936, a contigent of (resolutely) mutinous officers had planned to attack SAIONJI, but the plan was never put into action.
sen.cmt: I may have changed the yougo here, but what was written did not make sense.
sen.e: In the February 26 Incident of 1936, a contingent of (resolutely) mutinous officers had planned to attack Saionji, but the plan was never put into action.

sen.j: 襲撃を主張する者は元老西園寺を「君側の奸」の最たるものと見なしていたのに対し、否定派は西園寺を天皇とのパイプとして利用することを表向きの口実としていたと言われる。
sen.e: It is said that while those who advocated the attack viewed Genro SAIONJI as a prime example of a "wily vassal surrounding the Emperor", while those who opposed used an outward excuse of exploiting SAIONJI as a pipe between the Emperor.
sen.cmt: 「君側の奸」 = "Wily vassals surrounding the Emperor", 「定訳不明」
sen.e: It is said that those who advocated the attack viewed Genro SAIONJI as a prime example of a "wily vassal surrounding the Emperor," while those who opposed used an outward excuse of exploiting SAIONJI as a pipe between the Emperor.
sen.cmt: while …while --> X the japanese literally reads "pipe" I do not know how best to change this. Comma inside quotations
sen.e: It is said that those who advocated the attack viewed Genro Saionji as a prime example of a 'wily vassal surrounding the Emperor,' while those who opposed used an outward excuse of exploiting Saionji as a pipe between the Emperor.
sen.cmt: SAIONJI→Saionji原文の「」に合わせ"を'にスペース削除

sen.j: またこの事件に対し天皇が激怒し、自ら近衛部隊を率いて叛乱軍と戦うと言い出した時は、立憲君主制下の君主にあるまじき行動として、激しく諌言している。
sen.e: Furthermore, when the Emperor was enraged by this incident and said that he would lead the Konoe Troops himself to fight against the rebellious troops, he admonished him for taking an action unfit for a ruler under constitutional monarchy.

Furthermore, the Emperor was enraged by this incident and said that he would lead the Konoe Troops himself to fight against the rebellious troops, he admonished him for taking an action unfit for a ruler under constitutional monarchy.
sen.cmt: IMPORTANT: ambiguous pronoun reference "he admonished him" probably means SAIONJI admonished Showa… but not certain.
sen.e: Furthermore, the Emperor was enraged by this incident and said that he would lead the Konoe Troops himself to fight against the rebellious troops, Saionji admonished him for taking an action unfit for a ruler under constitutional monarchy.

sen.j: 東京駿河台の本邸の他に、静岡県御殿場町の便船塚別荘、同じく静岡県興津の坐漁荘、京都の清風荘の各別荘に隠棲し、元老として重きをなした。
sen.e: Aside from his main residence in Suruga-dai, Tokyo, he retired to his country houses of Binsenzuka country house in Gotenba-cho, Shizuoka Prefecture, Zagyo-so in Okitsu, also in Shizuoka Prefecture, and in Seifu-so in Kyoto, and he occupied an important position as a Genro.
