Aside from his main residence in Suruga-dai, Tokyo, he retired to his country houses of Binsenzuka country house in Gotenba-cho, Shizuoka Prefecture, Zagyo-so in Okitsu, also in Shizuoka Prefecture, and in Seifu-so in Kyoto, and he occupied an important position as a Genro.

Aside from his main residence in Suruga-dai, Tokyo, he retired to his villas of Binsenzuka-besso in Gotenba-cho, Shizuoka Prefecture, Zagyo-so in Okitsu, also in Shizuoka Prefecture, and in Seifu-so in Kyoto, and he occupied an important position as a Genro.

sen.j: 最晩年になると、避暑のために御殿場に滞在する以外は、年の大半を冬期が温暖な坐漁荘で過ごしている。
sen.e: In his very last years, other than staying in Gotenba to avoid the hot summer, he lived most of the year in Zagyo-so where it remained warm during winter.
In his very last years, other than staying in Gotenba to avoid the hot summer, he lived most of the year in Zagyo-where it remained warm during winter.
In his very last years, other than staying in Gotenba to avoid the hot summer, he lived most of the year in Zagyo-so where it remained warm during winter.

sen.j: 昭和12年（1937年）、組閣大命を受けた宇垣一成の組閣が軍部の反対により失敗すると、西園寺は元老辞退を申し出た。
sen.e: In 1937, SAIONJI requested to resign from his position as a Genro when Kazushige UGAKI, who received an order to form a cabinet, failed because of the resistance from the military.
In 1937, SAIONJI asked permission to resign from his position as a Genro when Kazushige UGAKI, who received an order to form a cabinet, failed because of resistance from the military.
In 1937, Saionji asked permission to resign from his position as a Genro when Kazushige UGAKI, who received an order to form a cabinet, failed because of resistance from the military.

sen.j: 元老拝辞はならなかったものの、内閣総理大臣奏薦は内大臣主導で行い、西園寺がそれを追認する形式となった。
sen.e: Even though he did not receive the permission to resign from his position as a Genro, advising of the appointment of the Prime Minister was led by the Minister of Imperial Household followed by SAIONJI accepting it.

Even though he did not receive permission to resign from his position as a Genro, advising of the appointment of the Prime Minister was led by the Minister of the Imperial Household followed by SAIONJI, who confirmed it.
sen.cmt: I recommend changing to adviseMENT deleted "the" accept --> confirm
sen.e: Even though he did not receive permission to resign from his position as a Genro, advising of the appointment of the Prime Minister was led by the Minister of the Imperial Household followed by Saionji, who confirmed it.

sen.j: 同年の第一次近衛内閣成立以降は次第に政治の表舞台から退き、反対し続けた日独伊三国軍事同盟成立の2ヶ月後の昭和15年（1940年）11月24日に死去した。
sen.e: After the First Konoe Cabinet was formed in the same year, he gradually retreated from the political stage, and he passed away on November 24, 1940, 2 months after the formation of Tripartie Military Pact, which he had continued to oppose.

After the First Konoe Cabinet was formed in the same year, he gradually retreated from the political stage, and he passed away on November 24, 1940, two months after the formation of Tripartie Military Pact, which he had continued to oppose.

After the First Konoe Cabinet was formed in the same year, he gradually retreated from the political stage, and he passed away on November 24, 1940, two months after the formation of Tripartite Military Pact, which he had continued to oppose.

sen.j: 贈従一位。
sen.e: He was awarded junior first court rank.
He was awarded junior first court rank.
He was awarded Juichii (Junior First rank).

sen.j: 最後の言葉は「いったいどこへ国をもってゆくのや」であったと伝えられる。
sen.e: It is said that his last words were "where on earth are they taking this country to?"
It is said that his last words were "where on earth are they taking this country to?"
It is said that his last words were 'where on earth are they taking this country to?'

sen.j: 期待していた近衛文麿に離反され、首相に推薦したことを最後まで後悔していたという。
sen.e: Fumimaro KONOE, on whom he had high expectations, seceded from him, and it is said that he regretted until the end that he had recommended him as a prime minister.
Fumimaro KONOE, of whom he had high expectations, distanced himself from him, and it is said that he regretted until the end that he had recommended him as a prime minister.
sen.cmt: on --> X of seceded --> distanced himself from
sen.e: Fumimaro KONOE, of whom he had high expectations, distanced himself from him, and it is said that he regretted until the end that he had recommended him as a prime minister.

sen.j: 昭和16年（1941年）には近衛内閣のブレーンを務める孫の西園寺公一が、ゾルゲ事件に関与したとして逮捕されている。
sen.e: In 1941, his grandson, Kinkazu SAIONJI, who was the brains in the Konoe Cabinet, was arrested for being involved in the Sorge Incident.
In 1941, his grandson, Kinkazu SAIONJI, who was the brains of the Konoe Cabinet, was arrested for being involved in the Sorge Incident.
In 1941, his grandson, Kinkazu SAIONJI, who was the brains of the Konoe Cabinet, was arrested for being involved in the Sorge Incident.

sen.j: 文部大臣時代の西園寺は、教養ある「市民」の育成を重視し、「科学や英語や女子教育を重視せよ」と言明していた。
sen.e: When he was Minister of Education he emphasized nurturing of educated "citizens", and he declared to "put an emphasis on science, English and education of girls."
When he was Minister of Education he emphasized nurturing of educated "citizens," and he tried to "put an emphasis on science, English and the education of girls."
sen.cmt: comma inside quotations, declared--> tried consider saying "young women" or "women" instead of girls for 女子
sen.e: When he was Minister of Education he emphasized nurturing of educated 'citizens,' and he tried to 'put an emphasis on science, English and the education of girls.'

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）には井上毅らが作った「教育勅語」に反対し、明治天皇から教育勅語改定の許可を得るとともに「第二次教育勅語」の作成に取り組んだ。
sen.e: In 1890, he opposed the "Education Ordinance" crafted by people including Tsuyoshi INOUE, and as soon as he obtained Emperor Meiji's permission to revise the "Education Ordinance" he worked on drafting "The Second Education Ordinance."
sen.cmt: 「教育勅語」 = "Education Ｏｒｄｉｎａｎｃｅ", "Japan - From Prehistory to Modern Times" by John Whitney Hall; Published by the Charles E. Tuttle Company Inc.
sen.e: In 1890, he opposed the "Education Ordinance" crafted by lawmakers including Tsuyoshi INOUE, and as soon as he obtained Emperor Meiji's permission to revise the "Education Ordinance" he worked on drafting "The Second Education Ordinance."

In 1890, he opposed the 'Education Ordinance' crafted by lawmakers including Tsuyoshi INOUE, and as soon as he obtained Emperor Meiji's permission to revise the Education Ordinance he worked on drafting 'The Second Education Ordinance.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'に原文に合わせて' '削除

sen.j: この「第二次教育勅語」の草案は西園寺家から立命館大学に寄贈されて現存している。
sen.e: The draft for this "Second Education Ordinance" was donated from SAIONJI Family to Ritsumeikan University, and it is currently kept there.
The original draft of this "Second Education Ordinance" was donated to Ritsumeikan University by the SAIONJI Family, and it is currently kept there.
The original draft of this 'Second Education Ordinance' was donated to Ritsumeikan University by the Saionji Family, and it is currently kept there.

sen.j: また、以下の教育機関の設立にも関っている。
sen.e: Furthermore, he was involved in the founding of the educational institutions below.
Furthermore, he was involved in the founding of the educational institutions below.
Furthermore, he was involved in the founding of the educational institutions below.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、 「私塾立命館」創設。
sen.e: "Ritsumeikan Private School" was founded in 1869.
"Ritsumeikan Private School" was founded in 1869.
'Ritsumeikan Private School' was founded in 1869.

sen.j: 中川小十郎（後の立命館大学創立者）の郷里の人間が多数学生となったが、京都府庁（太政官複都制）の差留命令により1年弱で閉鎖された。
sen.e: Many fellows from the hometown of Kojuro NAKAGAWA (later the founder of Ritsumeikan University) became its students, but it was closed in less than a year because of the closure order from Kyoto Prefectural Office (under dual capital system by Dajokan).
sen.cmt: 差留命令 = stop order, 「定訳不明」
sen.e: Many fellows Kojuro NAKAGAWA's hometown (later the founder of Ritsumeikan University) became its students, but it was closed in less than a year because of a closure order from the Kyoto Prefectural Office (under the dual capital system of Dajokan).
sen.cmt: changed phrasing the --> a added "the" and "of"
sen.e: Many fellows Kojuro NAKAGAWA's hometown (later the founder of Ritsumeikan University) became its students, but it was closed in less than a year because of a closure order from the Kyoto Prefectural Office (under the dual capital system of Dajokan).

sen.j: 西園寺は私塾立命館を閉鎖させた際、大層残念に思い再興を誓う。
sen.e: SAIONJI, upon closing of Ritsumeikan Private School, very much regretted and made a promise to reopen the school.
SAIONJI was very disappointed about the closure of Ritsumeikan Private School, and made a promise to reopen the school.
sen.cmt: regretted sounds like he did the closing, disappointed is better.
sen.e: Saionji was very disappointed about the closure of Ritsumeikan Private School, and made a promise to reopen the school.

sen.j: その後を継いだのが文部大臣当時の秘書官の中川だった。
sen.e: The one who succeeded him was NAKAGAWA, who served as the secretary when SAIONJI was Minister of Education.
sen.cmt: 「文部大臣当時」は「西園寺が文部大臣だった時の」という意味で訳してあります。
sen.e: His successor was NAKAGAWA, who served as the secretary when SAIONJI was Minister of Education.
His successor was Nakagawa, who served as the secretary when Saionji was Minister of Education.

sen.j: 現在の立命館大学は、中川がその名跡を譲り受けたもので、大学組織的としての連続性は絶たれたが西園寺は「私塾立命館」の後継として京都法政学校（現・立命館大学）創立にあたり様々な支援を行う事になる。
sen.e: Present day Ritsumeikan University has the name NAKAGAWA inherited, and even though SAIONJI's association with it as an institution of higher learning ended, he would contribute in various ways to establish Kyoto Law and Policy School (present day Ritsumeikan University) as a successor to "Ritsumeikan Private School."
sen.cmt: 名跡; 京都法政学校（現在の立命館大学） = Kyoto Law and Policy School (the present Ritsumeikan University)
sen.e: Present day Ritsumeikan University has the name NAKAGAWA inherited, and even though SAIONJI's association with it as an institution of higher learning ended, he contributed in various ways to establish Kyoto Law and Policy School (present day Ritsumeikan University) as a successor to "Ritsumeikan Private School."
sen.cmt: the use of 譲り受けた here troubles me. I do not know whether to write "the name it acquired from NAKAGAWA" or what. Minor phrasing changes
sen.e: Present day Ritsumeikan University was named after Ritsumeikan Private School, the name Nakagawa inherited, and even though Saionji's association with it as an institution of higher learning ended, he contributed in various ways to establish Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school (present day Ritsumeikan University) as a successor to 'Ritsumeikan Private School.'
sen.cmt: 「中川がその名跡を譲り受けたもので」の訳が曖昧です。NAKAGAWA→NakagawaSAIONJI→Saionji原文の「」に合わせ"を'に京都法政学校→Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school [http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/eng/profile/history/index.shtml]

sen.j: 西園寺の実弟末弘威麿が学園幹事に就任、同じく実弟の住友財閥当主住友友純が大口の寄付を行うなど、西園寺は自分の持つ政治力、人脈用いて京都法政学校（立命館大学）に協力した。
sen.e: SAIONJI used his political power and network to contribute to Kyoto Law and Policy School (Ritsumeikan University), including SAIONJI's younger biological brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, who became the executive officer of the school, and another younger biological brother, Tomoito SUMITOMO, head of Sumitomo Zaibatsu, who made a large amount of donation.

SAIONJI used his political power and network to contribute to Kyoto Law and Policy School (Ritsumeikan University), including SAIONJI's biological younger brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, who became the executive officer of the school, and another biological younger brother, Tomoito SUMITOMO, head of Sumitomo Zaibatsu, who donated large sums to the school.
sen.cmt: made a large amount of donation --> X donated large sums to the school. Biological younger is better than the reverse
sen.e: Saionji used his political power and network to contribute to Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school (Ritsumeikan University), including Saionji's biological younger brother, Takemaro SUEHIRO, who became the executive officer of the school, and another biological younger brother, Tomoito SUMITOMO, head of Sumitomo Zaibatsu, who donated large sums to the school.
sen.cmt: SAIONJI→Saionji京都法政学校→Kyoto Hosei School, an evening law school [http://www.ritsumei.ac.jp/eng/profile/history/index.shtml]

sen.j: また彼の寄付した多数の書籍は立命館大学（旧制）が大学昇格条件を満たすために為されたものであり、現在も「西園寺文庫」として立命館大学に貴重コレクションとして保存されている。
sen.e: Furthermore, he donated large number of books so that Ritsumeikan University (under the old system) would fulfill the requirement to be recognized as a university, and they are kept as a valuable collection named "SAIONJI Library" at Ritsumeikan University.

Furthermore, he donated large number of books so that Ritsumeikan University (under the old system) would fulfill the requirement to be recognized as a university, and they are kept as a valuable collection named the "SAIONJI Library" at Ritsumeikan University.
sen.cmt: added "the" consider changing the second instance of Ritsumeikan University. To "there" to reduce redundancy
sen.e: Furthermore, he donated large number of books so that Ritsumeikan University (under the old system) would fulfill the requirement to be recognized as a university, and they are kept as a valuable collection named the 'Saionji Library' at Ritsumeikan University.

sen.j: 一回目の寄贈は大正14年（1925年）5月に行われ、英仏書187冊であった。
sen.e: The first donation took place in May, 1925, and there were 187 British and French books.
The first donation took place in May, 1925, and consisted of 187 British and French books.
sen.cmt: judging by the Japanese, it sounds like this was the whole donation, not a part of it, so I changed it to "consisted of"
sen.e: The first donation took place in May, 1925, and consisted of 187 British and French books.

sen.j: その後、昭和5年（1930年）10月16日に和漢書約300冊、昭和13年（1938年）6月には西園寺家伝来の和綴本739部881冊の寄贈が為された。
sen.e: Later on, 300 Japanese and Chinese books were donated on October 16, 1930, and in June, 1938, 739 volumes and 881 traditionally bound Japanese books, which had been passed down in the SAIONJI family, were donated.

Later on, 300 Japanese and Chinese books were donated on October 16, 1930, and in June, 1938, 739 volumes and 881 traditionally bound Japanese books, which had been passed down in the SAIONJI family, were donated as well.
sen.cmt: As well is not in the original, but it helps it flow better.
sen.e: Later on, 300 Japanese and Chinese books were donated on October 16, 1930, and in June, 1938, 739 volumes and 881 traditionally bound Japanese books, which had been passed down in the Saionji family, were donated as well.

sen.j: この和綴書には、宮中儀式、有職故実関係、改元記録、和歌関係などの貴重文書が含まれている。
sen.e: These traditionally bound Japanese books contain valuable documents related to the ceremonial rites of the Imperial Court, yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past), record of era name changes and waka poems.

sen.e: These traditionally bound Japanese books contain valuable documents related to the ceremonial rites of the Imperial Court, yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past), records of the era, name changes, and waka poems.

sen.j: 西園寺が没した昭和15年（1940年）に立命館大学は、創立とその後の教育に大きく貢献した西園寺公望を立命館大学の「学祖」と取り決めた（但し、西園寺の美意識からか彼の遺言には「余の伝記を記すべからず」「余の碑を作るべからず」とともに「余を立命館の学祖とすべからず」の項があった）。
sen.e: In 1940, in the year SAIONJI passed away, Ritsumeikan University made an arrangement to designate Kimmochi SAIONJI, who contributed greatly to its establishment and education that followed, as the "founder" (however, perhaps from his sense of beauty, there was a page that read "do not inscribe my biography" and "do not create a monument for me" along with "do not designate me as the founder of Ritsumeikan" in his will.)
